description: Moscow correspondent Andrew Roth was in the courtroom when Alexei Navalny was sentenced to more than three years in prison. He tells Rachel Humphreys why it was such a dramatic moment – and what it could mean for the future of Russia’s opposition
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys with Andrew Roth. Produced by Courtney Yusuf and Axel Kacoutié. Executive producers are  Nicole Jackson, Mythili Rao andPhil Maynard. Additional production by Joe Koning

title: Valentines: how Phil and Jackie stay together
description: After 34 years together, Melbourne couple Phil Kafcaloudes and Jackie Rees-Kafcaloudes have had some tough conversations about kids, ageing and the meaning of commitment. Alexandra Spring talks to the couple about how they stay together
contributors: Reported by Alexandra Springand presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Miles Herbertand Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoniand Gabrielle Jackson.

title: The Nationals, net zero and the opportunity cost for Australia – with Lenore Taylor
description: This week, the Coalition debated what it would exempt from a policy to achieve a target of net zero emissions by 2050 – a policy and a target that do not currently exist. Guardian Australia editor Lenore Taylor and head of news Mike Ticher discuss what’s at stake while Australia fails to act on climate change
contributors: Hosted by Gabrielle Jackson with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher. Produced by Ryan Pemberton. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Will the Crown inquiry lead to a shakeup of Australia’s casino industry?
description: On Tuesday, an independent inquiry found that Crown Resorts – Australia’s largest gaming and entertainment group – is unsuitable to hold a casino licence in the state of New South Wales. Reporter Anne Davies steps through the key findings and outlines what this could mean for both Crown Resorts, and the future of the casino industry in Australia
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Anne Davies. Produced by Miles Herbert, Joe Koning and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Why the platypus is starting to disappear
description: The platypus has all but disappeared from South Australia and has been listed as vulnerable in Victoria. Now researchers are pushing for nationwide threatened species status. Guardian Australia’s environment reporter Graham Readfearn discusses what is happening to this incredibly unusual mammal
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Graham Readfearn. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Inside LA’s Covid crisis
description: Guardian US correspondent Sam Levin visits Martin Luther King Jr community hospital in Los Angeles county, an area battling one of the worst Covid outbreaks in the US
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys with Sam Levine. Produced by Sami Kent and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Collingwood football club and its reckoning with racism
description: After an independent investigation, the Do Better report highlighted a culture of structural racism at the Collingwood AFL club. After the report’s release, comments from the club’s president – media personality Eddie McGuire – raised concerns about how the issue would be dealt with.Guardian Australia’s Indigenous affairs editor Lorena Allam discusses the history of racist controversies linked to the club and the need for leadership when reckoning with structural racism
contributors: Reported by Lorena Allam and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Ryan Pemberton. Executive producers are Miles Martignoni and  Gabrielle Jackson

title: Craig Kelly and the dangers of misinformation - with Lenore Taylor
description: Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher join Full Story podcast host Gabrielle Jackson to discuss Scott Morrison’s public rebuke of Craig Kelly’s spread of Covid-19 misinformation and what responsibilities politicians and the media have in reporting on the pandemic and conspiracy theories
contributors: Hosted by Gabrielle Jackson with Lenore Taylor and Mike Ticher. Produced by Miles Martignoni

title: Dark money: who is bankrolling federal politics?
description: On Monday the yearly data on federal political donations was released, with the identity of donors and the amount they donated made available to the public. However, due to Australia’s lax donation laws, millions of dollars known as ‘dark money’ was not accounted for. Christopher Knaus explains how undeclared donations have infiltrated Australian politics and explores the flaws with the federal political donations system
contributors: Reported by Christopher Knausand presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoniand Gabrielle Jackson

title: The fight to change the laws gagging survivors of sexual assault
description: For decades, legislation in multiple Australian states outlawing the identification of sexual assault victims – with the possibility of jail time for both the survivor and the journalist – has prevented some survivors who wish to tell their stories from speaking out.In this episode, ‘Sandra’ and documentary-maker Blue Lucine speak about their three-year journey to tell Sandra’s story. Plus the journalist Nina Funnell explores the fight to change these laws
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Blue Lucine and Nina Funnell. Produced byJoe Koning and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: How will Biden deal with the US's pandemic problem?
description: Jonathan Freedland speaks to the Pulitzer prize-winning author and journalist Laurie Garrett about what Joe Biden needs to do to get a grip on the Covid crisis in the US
contributors: Presented by Jonathan Freedland  with Laurie Garrett. Produced by Danielle Stephens. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: The women fighting to be child-free
description: The pandemic has caused many people to think about whether they really want children. But practical options for women who choose not to remain limited. Health reporter Melissa Davey explores how women are being routinely denied access to permanent sterilisation procedures, and how that may be risking their health
contributors: Reported by Melissa Davey and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Miles Herbert, Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Why Brazilians are taking the Covid crisis into their own hands
description: Tom Phillips, the Guardian’s Latin America correspondent, looks at the surge of infections in the Brazilian state of Amazonas that has left many hospitals without the most basic supplies and has prompted yet more protests against Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Tom Phillips. Produced by Hannah Moore and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: What does a vaccinated Australia look like?
description: With the Covid-19 vaccine set to roll out in late February, life is about to change. In this episode, Guardian Australia health reporter Melissa Davey speaks about what the vaccines will actually do, who will get them first, and the long road ahead after vaccination
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Melissa Davey. Produced by Miles Herbert and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Two years on from Australia's banking royal commission, why has progress stalled?
description: When the banking royal commission wrapped up in early 2019, the government said it was committed to enacting change. Senior business reporter Ben Butler explains how two years on, most recommendations have either been delayed or abandoned
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Ben Butler. Produced by Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoniand Gabrielle Jackson

title: Amy McQuire on Invasion Day and the importance of truth-telling
description: Darumbal and South Sea Islander journalist Amy McQuire talks to Laura Murphy-Oates about how her new children’s book, Day Break, honours the resilience of Indigenous families as they mark 26 January. McQuire also explains why Australia Day is not a day for celebration, and the need to remember our history of frontier violence
contributors: Featuring Amy McQuire and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Joe Koning and Miles Herbert. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Will bitcoin ever be a viable currency?
description: In 2013 James Howells threw out a computer hard drive containing bitcoin. Last week he again asked his local council for permission to dig for it at his local dump as he believes it is now worth about £200m. The Guardian’s UK technology editor, Alex Hern, discusses the rise of bitcoin and whether it should be banned
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys with Alex Hern. Produced by Sam Colbert, T Kyle MacMahon and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: How Isaiah survived Australia's juvenile justice system
description: As a kid, Isaiah couldn’t escape the police. He went on to spend his teenage years in and out of youth detention. Now this young Dunghutti man is trying to change how our justice system treats Indigenous children
contributors: Reported and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater , Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: The Indigenous family fighting back against a legacy of police brutality
description: Thirra was six when he was taken from his family and 18 when a police van knocked him off his feet after a beating. Now he tells his story to Laura Murphy-Oates. After seeing footage of his son’s treatment at the hands of a New South Wales officer he speaks about the cycle of police brutality he’s spent his life trying to escape – and the despair he felt seeing his children treated the same way.
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates, produced by Jake Morcom, Ellen Leabeater, Joe Koning and Jon Tjhia. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Lenore Taylor on why truth, facts and journalism are more important to democracy than ever
description: In 2020 the media was faced with the dual challenge of covering a pandemic and an avalanche of misinformation. In this episode of Full Story, Guardian Australia editor Lenore Taylor discusses how Australia’s response compared with other countries and the challenges ahead for journalism
contributors: Presented by Lucy Clark with Lenore Taylor and introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Miles Herbert, Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Joëlle Gergis on mourning and making sense of what we have lost on the frontlines of the climate crisis
description: Climate scientist and writer Joëlle Gergis speaks about the incalculable loss already suffered due to climate change and why the only way forward is to acknowledge the grief rather than ignore it
contributors: Presented by Lucy Clark with Joëlle Gergis. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates and produced by Miles Herbert and Joe Koning

title: Jennifer Mills on how pandemic solidarity can help us tackle climate change and inequality
description: Author Jennifer Mills reflects on how the idea of breath ties together the three crises of 2020: the climate crisis, racial injustice and the pandemic. She compares Australia’s ‘gas-led recovery’ plan to Europe’s willingness to embrace solutions to the climate emergency as part of its economic recovery
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Jennifer Mills. Produced by Miles Herbert and Ryan Pemberton. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Gabrielle Chan on the challenges and opportunities in Australian food production
description: Journalist and author Gabrielle Chan examines the weaknesses in global supply chains and how we can learn from small businesses that helped to fill gaps that were exposed by the Covid-19 pandemic
contributors: Presented by Lucy Clark with Gabrielle Chan and introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Jake Morcom, Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Kim Scott on using fragments of the past to create a better future
description: Noongar author Kim Scott has been combing through colonial records, looking for entries related to his people’s culture and history. In this interview he describes travelling across Noongar country, piecing these records together with the knowledge of elders and community members – both Indigenous and non-Indigenous
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Kim Scott. Produced by Jake Morcom and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Jane Rawson on disaster inequality and how to cope with what the future may hold
description: Australian novelist and environmentalist Jane Rawson explains why trying to keep yourself safe from the effects of climate change can only go so far and why the only way to be truly safe from global heating is to totally change the way we run the world
contributors: Presented by Lucy Clark with Jane Rawson. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates, produced by Karishma Luthria, Jake Morcom, Ellen Leabeater and Ryan Pemberton. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Richard McGregor on where to for Australia's tumultuous relationship with China in 2021
description: In 2014 Chinese president Xi Jinping came to Australia to address the parliament. Just over six years later, Australian politicians don’t seem to be able to get a Chinese politician to answer their phone calls. Author Richard McGregor explains why the once-cosy relationship between the two countries can never go back to the way it was
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Richard McGregor. Produced by Miles Herbert and Ryan Pemberton. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Nyadol Nyuon on race, survival and the need for empathy
description: Lawyer and human rights advocate Nyadol Nyuon on how the pandemic brought back memories of her childhood in a refugee camp in Kenya and why empathy must be at the heart of our decision-making
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates with Nyadol Nyuon. Produced by Karishma Luthria and Joe Koning

title: Revisited: the clitoris coverup
description: Medical textbooks are full of anatomical pictures of the penis, but the clitoris barely rates a mention, with many medical professionals uncomfortable even talking about it. Reporter Calla Wahlquist and associate news editor Gabrielle Jackson explain the history and science of the clitoris, and speak to the scientists and artists dedicated to demystifying it
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Calla Wahlquist and Gabrielle Jackson. Produced by Ellen Leabeater,  Karishma Luthria and Joe Koning. Miles Martignoni is the executive producer

title: Revisited: Justice for Tanya Day
description: In 2017, 55-year-old Yorta Yorta woman Tanya Day suffered a devastating fall in a police cell. Shortly before Christmas, she passed away in a Melbourne hospital. Since then, Day’s family has campaigned to change the law she was arrested for, and to change the way Indigenous people are treated in Australia’s justice system. Calla Wahlquist explores the coronial inquest into the death and her family’s campaign for justice
contributors: Reported by Calla Wahlquist and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Miles Herbert, Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Revisited: What happens when the oceans heat up?
description: As we continue to see impacts from global heating around the world, research in the places first affected becomes increasingly more important. Off the coast of Tasmania the oceans are heating and it’s one of a handful of places around the world that have seen an increase of 2C in a short time. In this episode of Full Story, we go to Tasmania to see how this has impacted on fishing industries and marine ecosystems
contributors: Reported by Adam Morton. Hosted by Gabrielle Jackson. Produced by Jake Morcom, Ellen Leabeater. Additional production by Miles Herbert. Field recording by David Fanner.  Miles Martignoni is the executive producer

title: Revisited: How to make love last
description: Morie and Liz met in London in 1980 but she was from Australia and he was from Iran. In this episode of Full Story, they tell how they overcame war, distance and disapproving parents to form a bond that has lasted 40 years
contributors: Hosted by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by   Alexandra Spring. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Joe Koning and Miles Herbert . Miles Martignoni is the executive producer

title: Revisited: Bruce Pascoe on overcoming a summer of trauma
description: Last summer the celebrated author Bruce Pascoe found himself in the middle of two life-changing events: the East Gippsland bushfires, and a very public controversy surrounding his bestselling book Dark Emu and his Indigenous identity. In this episode, Guardian Australia’s Indigenous affairs editor Lorena Allam speaks to Pascoe about how he has rebounded, pouring his efforts into a historic agricultural project in Mallacoota
contributors: Reported by Lorena Allam and Isabella Moore. Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Gabrielle Jacksonand Miles Martignoni

title: Looking back at 2020: a year like no other
description: The past 12 months has been a year of non-stop headlines – coronavirus aside. The Guardian’s editor-in-chief, Katharine Viner, joins Anushka Asthana to reflect on the stories of 2020. There was the killing of George Floyd and the global anti-racism movement Black Lives Matter, and then the US election in which Americans voted president Donald Trump out of office. And the biggest story of all: the continuing climate crisis which, despite a pandemic-induced reduction in travel, resulted in only a 7% drop in global emissions
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana with  Katharine Viner; produced by Mythili Rao with  Nicholas Alexander. Executive producers Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: Animals, aliens and the news you may have missed in 2020
description: Animals running rampant, alien life and that infamous Zoom call – these are just some of the stories you might have missed amid the chaos this year. Columnists Brigid Delaney and Van Badham join host Gabrielle Jackson to discuss the news that flew under the radar in 2020
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Brigid Delaney and Van Badham. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Laura Murphy-Oates. Executive Producer Miles Martignoni

title: Only the good stuff: the lighter moments from pop culture in 2020
description: It’s been a year. While there’s plenty about 2020 you probably don’t want to remember, there are some happy moments we can all take some joy from
contributors: Reported by Alyx Gorman and Steph Harmon. Presented by  Laura Murphy-Oates ; produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. Executive producers  Gabrielle Jackson and Miles Martignoni

title: Life after Christchurch: one survivor's journey of recovery and reckoning
description: On 15 March 2019 a man entered the Al Noor mosque in Christchurch, New Zealand and shot Temel Atacocugu nine times. That day 51 people were killed, but Temel survived.Reporter Charlotte Graham-McLay follows Temel’s journey – through surgeries, the terrorist’s sentencing and a royal commission – as he tries to recover and rebuild his life.
contributors: Reported by Charlotte Graham-McLay and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Cheyne Anderson, Belinda Lopez, Ellen Leabeaterand Ryan Pemberton. Miles Martignoniand Gabrielle Jacksonare the executive producers.

title: Surviving a shark attack
description: The 2020 death toll from shark attacks in Australia is the highest in 86 years. We speak to Chantelle Doyle, who was bitten by a shark while surfing in Port Macquarie and lived to tell the tale. Plus, Graham Readfearn on the science around sharks and shark attacks.
contributors: Reported by Graham Readfearn and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater , Karishma Luthria and  Joe Koning. The Executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Stuck in an endless loop
description: One family. All devout pacifists, they all fled the same dangers and all of them are recognised refugees in Australia. The mother and children were resettled from overseas and now have permanent protection. But their father arrived by boat. He lives in anxious uncertainty, enduring an opaque reapplication process that could result in his being torn away from them
contributors: Presented by Sisonke Msimang with Ben Doherty Produced by Miles Herbert and Kara Jensen-Mackinnon. Sound design byRyan Pemberton with original music by Lama Zakharia. Editorial support by Miles Martignoni.

title: One year on, why are bushfire-hit communities struggling for funding?
description: In the lead-up to Christmas, some communities are still struggling to rebuild homes and vital infrastructure damaged by last summer’s bushfires. We speak to northern New South Wales resident Melinda Plesman about how she’s coping a year after losing her house. Plus, Christopher Knaus investigates how one grants program has allocated money for fire-hit communities.
contributors: Reported by Christopher Knausand presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater andJoe Koning. Executive producers are Miles Martignoniand Gabrielle Jackson.

title: Three women on their fight for abortion rights in Poland
description: Academic Agnieszka Graff, lawyer Karolina Więckiewicz and gynaecologist Anna Parzyńska discuss their fight for abortion rights. An attempt by authorities to impose a near-total ban on terminations has sparked mass demonstrations across the country
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana with Agnieszka Graff, Karolina Więckiewicz and Anna Parzyńska. Produced by Elizabeth Cassin and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: What happens when the government wants to send you back to an unsafe place?
description: Arman’s claim for asylum was rejected because the Australian government thought it was safe for him to return to Afghanistan. While this is no longer the government’s view, Australia’s appeal system means the decision still stands. In this episode of Full Story, Arman explains how he has nowhere to turn – his only chance to stay in Australia is if Peter Dutton personally intervenes
contributors: Presented by Sisonke Msimang with Ben Doherty. Produced by Kara Jensen-Mackinnon and Miles Herbert, sound design by Ryan Pemberton with original music by Lama Zakharia. Editorial support by Miles Martignoni. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: What happened to the asylum seekers medically evacuated to Australia?
description: After the Medevac bill was passed in 2019 almost 200 people were deemed by a panel of doctors to require medical attention that required they be taken to Australia. They are now mostly locked in hotels or detention centres, none have been sent back so far. So what is the future for these refugees?
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Michael Green. Produced by Cheyne Anderson and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: The Nobel peace prize winner fighting a war in Ethiopia
description: Ethiopia’s prime minister was feted by the international community as a reformer and a peacemaker. Now, as the Guardian’s Jason Burke explains, he has launched a major military campaign in the north of his country that threatens the stability of the region
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Jason Burke and Yohannes Woldemariam. Produced by Courtney Yusuf and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson

title: The Crown: is the Netflix drama fact or fiction?
description: Royal correspondent Jennie Bond, who has covered some of the most dramatic years of the monarchy, discusses whether The Crown is an accurate depiction of palace life
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana, produced by Rose de Larrabeiti , Courtney Yusuf, Mythili Rao and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: Could Trump be indicted? And could he pardon himself?
description: As the US justice department investigates an alleged ‘bribery for pardon’ scheme at the White House, Jonathan Freedland and David Smith delve into the many possible legal issues Donald Trump could face after 20 January
contributors: Presented by Jonathan Freedland and reported by David Smith. Produced by Danielle Stephens and Esther Opoku-Gyeni. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: How do you say goodbye forever?
description: In this episode we hear Elaheh’s story. She had to suddenly flee Iran, not realising she might never see her family again. Now a recognised refugee in Australia with a young son, her visa’s restrictions dictate whether her son will ever meet the strong women who raised her  This episode is part of our new series Temporary – you can listen to all the episodes here
contributors: Presented by Sisonke Msimang with Ben Doherty. Produced by Kara Jensen-Mackinnon and Miles Herbert, sound design by Ryan Pemberton with original music by Lama Zakharia. Editorial support by Miles Martignoni. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: How one tweet laid bare Australia and China’s tense relationship
description: A tweet from a Chinese government spokesman – with a computer generated image appearing to show an Australian soldier holding a knife to the throat of an Afghan child – has provoked outrage from Australian politicians, and other Western democracies. However, this is just the latest incident in what experts say is a serious breakdown in the relationship between Australia and China.Reporter Daniel Hurst on the escalating tensions with China, the devastating economic cost to Australia and the future of this diplomatic relationship.
contributors: Reported by Daniel Hurstand presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Jake Morcom, Ellen Leabeaterand Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoniand Marni Cordell

title: How can Gladys Berejiklian defend pork barrelling?
description: The NSW premier, Gladys Berejiklian, has been at the centre of a number of scandals in recent months, the latest involving accusations her government spent $140m of public funds to shore up Coalition seats ahead of the 2019 election. Investigative reporter Anne Davies explores whether Berejiklian is still fit to lead the state
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Anne Davies. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Marni Cordell

title: He risked his life fighting the Californian wildfires, now he faces deportation
description: For weeks, the Guardian US reporter Sam Levin has been speaking to Bounchan Keola, who is being detained by US Immigration and Customs Enforcement (Ice) and facing deportation to Laos, a country he left when he was four, despite having risked his life to fight wildfires in California this year
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Sam Levin. Produced by Sam Colbert, Rose de Larrabeiti and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Why Australia has no clear policy on electric vehicles
description: Australia is lagging behind many countries on the uptake of electric vehicles. Environment editor Adam Morton explains that there are a lot of practical reasons for this, but it’s also because of government-led scare campaigns and disincentives
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Adam Morton. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Joe Koning and Jake Morcom. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Marni Cordell

title: Is former Elite boss Gérald Marie the Harvey Weinstein of the fashion industry?
description: Wendy Walsh was 17 when she moved to Paris to be a model. Within weeks of arriving, Walsh alleges, she was raped by Gérald Marie. She is one of 16 women who have spoken to the investigative reporter Lucy Osborne, who has spent the past year looking into whether Marie was a sexual predator
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Lucy Osborne with Wendy Walsh. Produced by Hannah Moore and Nicholas Cox . The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Justice for Centrelink robodebt victims?
description: The government has reached a massive $1.2bn dollar settlement over its bungled robodebt scheme. It sounds like a lot – but for many victims, whose lives were upturned by the mass Centrelink debt collection program, it only amounts to a couple of hundred dollars in compensation. And as Luke Henriques-Gomes tells Full Story, there has been no mea culpa from the government, nor have the scheme’s architects lost their jobs
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Luke Henriques-Gomes. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni, Gabrielle Jackson and Marni Cordell

title: How Australia put 30,000 people in limbo
description: When he was a teenager Zaki fled a Taliban death warrant to find somewhere safe. Instead, he found himself impounded in the politics of fear that Australian leaders have been stoking for decades. He is one of 30,000 refugees and asylum seekers in the ‘legacy caseload’, kept silent by a system that holds permanent protection out of reach.  A legal limbo without end: the people who came by boat but never found home in Australia
contributors: Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates. Presented by Sisonke Msimang with Ben Doherty. Produced by KKara Jensen-Mackinnon and Miles Herbert, sound design by Ryan Pemberton with original music by Lama Zakharia. Editorial support by Miles Martignoni

title: South Australia’s coronavirus outbreak and the dangers of a casual workforce
description: After facing its first outbreak in months, South Australia’s hard lockdown came to an end on Sunday, three days earlier than scheduled. The state government has directed much of the blame for this confusing response on one hotel worker.Reporter Melissa Davey talks about why one individual is not to blame and how this outbreak has exposed deeply rooted problems with both Australia’s Covid-19 response and the makeup of our workforce.
contributors: Reported by Melissa Davey and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates.  Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson.

title: US minority voters and the future of the Republican party
description: Gary Younge looks at the history of US voting rights and what the changing demographics of the country mean for Republicans
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana with Gary Younge. Produced by Elizabeth Cassin and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: How Samuel Paty's murder reignited France's free speech debate
description: The beheading of a schoolteacher who had shown his class cartoons of the prophet Muhammad during a lesson on free speech has rekindled a debate in France about secularism and the state’s role in regulating free expression
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Jon Henley and Nabila Ramdani. Produced by Courtney Yusuf and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates and Joe Koning

title: Holding Australia to account for allegations of war crimes
description: The Brereton report, four years in the making, has found credible evidence that Australian special forces were involved in the murder of 39 Afghan civilians. It also detailed the brutal nature of some of these alleged killings, and alleged attempts to cover them up.Reporter Christopher Knaus talks about the consequences and how it all came to light
contributors: Reported by Christopher Knaus and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Jake Morcom, Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. Executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson.

title: What is modern monetary theory and could it fix Australia’s problems?
description: Australia entered a recession in September for the first time in nearly 30 years. As countries around the world face similar economic woes, some are calling for a new way for governments to think about the economy. In this episode of Full Story, University of Newcastle professor Bill Mitchell and economics reporter Martin Farrer explain what modern monetary theory is and how it could work
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Martin Farrer. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Joe Koning, Hannah Izzard and Jon Tjhia. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: US election: what will it take for Donald Trump to concede defeat?
description: The US president is continuing to dispute the result of the election and, far from offering his concession, is instead claiming victory. Lawrence Douglas describes what Donald Trump’s behaviour means for the country
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Lawrence Douglas. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates . Produced by Joshua Kelly , Elizabeth Cassin and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard . Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates with additional production from Joe Koning

title: Coercive control: Hannah Clarke’s parents on the abuse that preceded their daughter’s murder
description: The murder of Hannah Clarke and her three children by her former partner in February provoked widespread soul-searching about the lives lost to domestic violence in Australia. Some experts say that intimate partner murder is the most predictable type of homicide and that by searching for a pattern of behaviour known as coercive control we can saves lives. In this episode of Full Story, Clarke’s parents talk about Hannah’s relationship with her ex-partner and what they wish they had known about coercive control
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Amanda Gearing. Produced by Joe Koning, Ellen Leabeater and Jake Morcom. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Being diagnosed with ADD as an adult
description: For a long time, attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHAD) and ADD (without the hyperactivity aspect) were viewed as disorders that predominantly affected children. But recently there’s been an increase in adult diagnoses. Today we speak to Adrian Chiles about being diagnosed in his 50s as well as Prof Susan Young on how it manifests differently in children and adults
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana with Adrian Chiles and Professor Susan Young. Produced by Sam Colbert and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Dying to work: the dangers facing Australia's food delivery drivers
description: Ordering food delivery via the convenience of an app became a regular feature in our locked-down cities. But at the heart of this industry lies a tale of insecure work, where delivery drivers have few rights and dangerous work conditions. After the deaths of several deliver drivers, Naaman Zhou examines the risks facing those in this growing line of work
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Naaman Zhou. Produced by Miles Herbert, Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: When will Australia have a Covid-19 vaccine?
description: Hopes were raised around the world this week as news broke about a breakthrough in the race to develop a Covid-19 vaccine. Interim results show the Pfizer vaccine is 90% effective. But how much do we actually know about this trial and who will get it first?
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Melissa Davey. Produced by Jake Morcom and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Gabrielle Jackson and Miles Martignoni

title: 'Jesus, what an idiot I was!' Helen Garner on revisiting her past to publish her diaries
description: In this discussion between Helen Garner and Michael Williams for Guardian Australia’s monthly Zoom book club, the author talks about the difficulties of publishing her diaries, and her fascination with systems of life and death.  Read an extract from One Day I’ll Remember This
contributors: Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates and hosted by Michael Williams. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers of Full Story are Gabrielle Jackson and Miles Martignoni

title: US election 2020: can Joe Biden unite America?
description: After days of tense counting in key states, Joe Biden was confirmed as the winner of the US election, beating the incumbent Donald Trump. But as David Smith explains, his job of uniting the country begins now – and it won’t be easy
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by David Smith. Produced by Hannah Moore, Courtney Yusuf and Nicholas Cox. THe executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson

title: The clitoris coverup: why do we know so little? – podcast
description: Medical textbooks are full of anatomical pictures of the penis, but the clitoris barely rates a mention, with many medical professionals uncomfortable even talking about it. Reporter Calla Wahlquist and associate news editor Gabrielle Jackson explain the history and science of the clitoris, and speak to the scientists and artists dedicated to demystifying it
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Calla Wahlquist and Gabrielle Jackson. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Karishma Luthria and Joe Koning.

title: What kind of president would Joe Biden make? – podcast
description: There’s still no clear winner in the US election but both candidates have paths to victory that could happen anytime this week. But if Joe Biden does succeed, what kind of president would he make? In this episode of Full Story, we look at his past to learn about what he may do in the future  Paths to US election victory: what Trump and Biden need to win
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Evan Osnos. Produced by Rose de Larrabeiti and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: The US election and what a Biden win would mean for Australia
description: Both Joe Biden and Donald Trump still have paths to victory in the US election but the contest is narrowing substantially. In this episode of Full Story, Guardian Australia editor Lenore Taylor and Simon Jackman from the US Studies Centre discuss what’s unfolding and what a Biden presidency would mean for Australia
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Lenore Taylor and Simon Jackman

title: US election 2020: who are the voters sticking with Trump?
description: Donald Trump faces a major challenge to repeat the swing-states victory he achieved in 2016. The Guardian’s Chris McGreal takes a US election road trip and meets voters who explain why they are standing by the White House incumbent
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Chris McGreal. Produced by Elizabeth Cassin and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adpated by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: How the US election night unfolded and what happens next
description: Before votes started to be counted many pollsters had projected a big win for the Democratic candidate, Joe Biden, but with the major swing states too close to call at the time of recording, his route to the White House appeared to be narrowing
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Ed Pilkington, Daniel Strauss, David Smith, Oliver Laughland, Nina Lakhani and Vivian Ho. Produced by Mythili Rao, Hannah Moore, Sam Colbert, Courtney Yusuf and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates and Miles Martignoni

title: US election 2020: Trump and the rise of white supremacist extremism
description: White supremacist extremism is the most lethal terrorism threat to the United States. It’s a hateful ideology that the Guardian’s Lois Beckett says has infected many parts of American society
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Lois Beckett with Demetria Hester. Produced by Courtney Yusuf and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: How Annastacia Palaszczuk brought together a divided state
description: An election victory in Queensland was always predicted to be close. It relied on bringing together voters on all sides of some of Australia’s most divisive issues: climate change, mining and state borders during the pandemic. Annastacia Palaszczuk overcame expectations and looks set to bring in a majority Labor government. How did she do it?
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Ben Smee. Produced by Ellen Leabeater. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: The Wait part 5: don't forget to smile
description: In the fifth part of our series examining the plight of refugees in Indonesia, we hear the story of what has happened to Mozhgan’s family. Her dad Amir has struggled the most. In episode one we heard him in the midst of a shocking crisis. That was a year ago. How is he now?  Listen to The Wait part 1: a paradox and a dilemma Listen to The Wait part 2: we say it’s chance Listen to The Wait part 3: the place where we are kept Listen to The Wait part 4: if there is a god
contributors: Co-hosted by Mozhgan Moarefizadeh. Produced by Nicole Curby, supervising producing by Michael Green with Miles Martignoni. Sound design and mixing by Bec Fary. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: US election 2020: can the Democrats win back trust in Ohio?
description: The race in Ohio has long been a reliable guide to the US election: the state’s winner usually goes on to win the presidency. In 2016, it broke decisively for Trump, but this year there are signs that its voters are turning away from the president
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Oliver Laughland and John Russo. Produced by Mythili Rao and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: The Wait part 4: if there is a God
description: In the fourth part of our series examining the plight of refugees in Indonesia, Mozhgan and her friend Elina, from Sudan, have a disagreement about beliefs. When the future is impossible to see, faith can be a rock – or it can shatter completely. In this episode we look at how, in their quest to cope, some refugees are taking matters into their own hands  Listen to The Wait part 1: a paradox and a dilemma Listen to The Wait part 2: we say it’s chance Listen to The Wait part 3: the place where we are kept
contributors: Co-hosted by Mozhgan Moarefizadeh. Produced by Nicole Curby, supervising producing by Michael Green with Miles Martignoni. Sound design and mixing by Bec Fary. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: An Australian guide to the US election
description: In just under a week, the United States heads to the polls in what some have called the most important election in American history. Josephine Tovey explains everything you need to know
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Josephine Tovey. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Why are so many Americans being denied a vote?
description: Millions of voters will be unable to cast their ballot in this year’s US presidential election and those affected will be disproportionately first-time voters and from minority groups, reports Sam Levine
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Sam Levine. Produced by Mythili Rao and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Introduced by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Is a just transition from coal to renewables possible?
description: Port Augusta once supplied 40% of South Australia’s electricity through its huge coal-fired power station. But the town saw the writing on the wall for fossil fuels and began to campaign for a transition to renewable energy to secure jobs for future generations. Jake Morcom and Adam Morton discuss what went wrong for the town’s promising renewables projects
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Adam Morton and Jake Morcom. Produced by Miles Herbert, Joe Koning and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producers are Tom Morton and Miles Martignoni

title: The Wait part 3: the place where we are kept
description: This is the third episode in a five-part series examining the plight of refugees in Indonesia. As protests rage in cities across Indonesia, Yousif from Sudan takes to the streets despite threats of arrest. Mozhgan can’t travel, so Nicole investigates, visiting shelters in Makassar and Batam. Who’s on the streets and why are they willing to risk it all to raise their voices?  Listen to The Wait part 1: a paradox and a dilemma Listen to The Wait part 2: we say it’s chance
contributors: Co-hosted by Mozhgan Moarefizadeh. Produced by Nicole Curby, supervising producing by Michael Green with Miles Martignoni. Sound design and mixing by Bec Fary. Introduced by Gabrielle Jackson.

title: US presidential debate: a much calmer affair – but who won?
description: As the two US presidential candidates left the stage in Tennessee after the final debate of the campaign, Jonathan Freedland and Richard Wolffe talk through the biggest moments of the night
contributors: Presented by Jonathan Freedland with Richard Wolffe. Produced by Danielle Stephens

title: US election 2020: Joe Biden's and Donald Trump's possible paths to power
description: Lauren Gambino, political correspondent for Guardian US, discusses which states Democratic nominee Joe Biden will need to win to take the White House, and what Donald Trump will need to do to retain the presidency
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana with Lauren Gambino. Produced by Sam Colbert; sound design by Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Additional production Miles Herbert

title: Could Jacinda Ardern's 'politics of kindness' work in other countries?
description: New Zealand’s prime minister has led the Labour party to its best result in 50 years. Her campaign was run on polite politics and a rejection of misinformation. Eleanor Ainge Roy looks at Jacinda Ardern’s rise and what other countries can learn from it
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Eleanor Ainge Roy. Produced by Jake Morcom, Joe Koning and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Can Covid-19 change how Australians value the great outdoors?
description: Much of Australia has a climate that allows people to enjoy the outdoors most days of the year, but tough Covid-19 restrictions have limited the use of public space. Josephine Tovey looks at what’s changing in cities and considers how governments can make public spaces safely accessible for everyone
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson with Josephine Tovey; produced by Ellen Leabeater. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: How QAnon spread to Australia and spilled out into real life
description: In the second of a two-part special on QAnon, we look at how the baseless internet conspiracy theory spread to Australia, embroiling a Nationals MP from country Victoria who had to defend herself against a concerted campaign of vicious lies
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Michael McGowan. Produced by Cheyne Anderson , Joe Koning and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Full Story special: did anyone win the first US presidential debate?
description: It was tipped to be an explosive event and it didn’t disappoint. Jonathan Freedland and Guardian columnist Richard Wolffe discuss the highlights and lowlights of the first presidential election debate of 2020
contributors: Presented by Jonathan Freedland with Richard Wolffe; produced by Danielle Stephens

title: The dangerous global spread of the QAnon conspiracy theory
description: In the first of two episodes, Anushka Asthana and Julia Carrie Wong explore how QAnon has spread from the US to other parts of the world, including Australia, tracing its origins in a climate of deep uncertainty over the Covid pandemic and widespread social unrest
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana with Julia Carrie Wong, produced by Mythili Rao and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: How the death of Ruth Bader Ginsburg could change America
description: She was a pioneer of women’s rights and a liberal icon of the US supreme court. Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s death last week may alter the course of American politics and lead to a seismic shift towards a more conservative court for years to come
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reporded by Moira Donegan. Produced by Serena Barker-Singh and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Gabrielle Jackson

title: Inside the rescue of the pilot whales stranded in Tasmania
description: A huge rescue effort kicked off when hundreds of pilot whales beached themselves in Macquarie Harbour off the west coast of Tasmania. Graham Readfearn explains how the rescue operation unfolded and reveals what a unique and intelligent species this is
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Graham Readfearn with Adam Morton. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: How does Australia balance its economic dependency on China with its democratic values?
description: Australia’s economy has benefited enormously from China’s extraordinary growth and the trade links have helped make Australia one of the world’s richest countries. But the relationship is increasingly strained. Daniel Hurst looks at the history of that relationship and what the options are for the future
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Daniel Hurst. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Protecting history: how Juukan Gorge could change mining forever
description: When Rio Tinto destroyed a 46,000-year-old Indigenous heritage site, the world’s anger took the company by surprise. Now investors are demanding more transparency in how mining companies deal with traditional owners. Lorena Allam and Calla Wahlquist look at what’s changed since Rio blasted Juukan Gorge
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Lorena Allam and Calla Wahlquist. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Donald Trump and a pattern of alleged sexual assault
description: In an exclusive interview with the Guardian, the former model Amy Dorris talked to Lucy Osborne about allegations that Donald Trump sexually assaulted her at the US Open tennis tournament more than two decades ago, in an alleged incident that left her feeling ‘sick’ and ‘violated’
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana with Lucy Osborne and Amy Dorris, produced by Joshua Kelly and Nicholas Cox; executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: How Queensland's election became all about the premier and the pandemic
description: With just six weeks to go before Queensland voters head to the polls, it seems people can talk about little else than Covid-19. Annastacia Palaszczuk’s handling of the crisis has been well-received so far, but as Ben Smee explains, there are potential pitfalls in running a presidential-style campaign during a pandemic
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Ben Smee. Produced by Joe Koning and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: What does the poisoning of Alexei Navalny tell us about Vladimir Putin's Russia?
description: Luke Harding tells Anushka Asthana the alleged attack on Navalny has all the hallmarks of a state-sponsored hit. As Navalny appears to be recovering from the incident, western leaders are demanding answers from Russia
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana with Luke Harding; produced by Rachel Humphreys and Nicholas Cox; executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard; additional production by Joe Koning

title: Katharine Murphy and Adam Morton on the government's gas plan
description: Scott Morrison has been talking about the importance of gas in Australia’s energy market since the beginning of the year – but his speech this week raised more questions than it answered. Katharine Murphy and Adam Morton explain how we got here and what it means for the country’s climate commitments
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Katharine Murphy and Adam Morton. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Will social bubbles break the loneliness of living alone in Melbourne during lockdown?
description: After 10 weeks of various stages of lockdown in Melbourne, a new policy was announced to help single people who live alone, to allow them to spend time with others by forming a “social bubble”. While many people are excited about the prospect of being able to spend time with another person, others have questioned how practical some of the rules are.
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Josh Taylor. Produced by Joe Koning, Miles Herbert and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: The Austrian ski resort that became the centre of Europe’s Covid-19 outbreak
description: When Nigel Mallender headed to Ischgl from the UK in March, he was looking forward to a fun-packed break with friends. Just four days later, he and thousands of other tourists were desperately trying to leave after authorities became aware of coronavirus cases. Mallender and the Guardian’s Philip Oltermann discuss the fallout from that week
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Philip Oltermann. Produced by Elizabeth Cassin and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are NNicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Additional production by Gabrielle Jackson

title: How Julie was forced to fight the system that was supposed to protect her
description: Neil Punchard is a police officer who leaked a domestic violence victim’s address to her violent ex-husband. The case shocked Australia and has campaigners asking why the officer is still employed by Queensland police. Ben Smee recalls all Julie has been through and raises questions the police force has yet to answer
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Ben Smee. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning with assistance from Miles Herbert. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Is democracy in America under threat?
description: As the US election draws closer, the Guardian’s Ed Pilkington hears from civil leaders on their fears for the integrity of the process and the future of their democracy
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana, reported by Ed Pilkington. Produced by Joshua Kelly and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: What can we learn from Melbourne's stage-four lockdown?
description: The World Health Organization has called on governments to be clear about which Covid-19 restrictions are most effective to avoid blanket lockdowns in future outbreaks. With numbers now dropping in Melbourne and a roadmap announced, which measures have good evidence behind them and which don’t?
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Melissa Davey. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: David Marr speaks to Katharine Murphy about Scott Morrison and pandemic politics
description: Guardian Australia’s political editor Katharine Murphy has spent most of this year focusing on the Coalition’s response to the coronavirus and analysing what this tells us about how Scott Morrison governs. In this episode of Full Story, David Marr interviews her about the PM’s problem-solving approach and his dislike of tough questions
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and David Marr, reported by Katharine Murphy. Produced by Hannah Izzard and Miles Martignoni

title: Will Trump’s law and order gamble pay off?
description: The Guardian’s US Washington DC bureau chief, David Smith, discusses Donald Trump’s law and order gamble on the election, and how it is impacting on Democratic candidate Joe Biden’s campaign
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by David Smith. Produced by Mythili Rao and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard.  Adapted by Gabrielle Jackson

title: Australia's environment laws: are they about to get even weaker?
description: A recent review of the laws around Australia’s natural environment found they were failing. Now the government is hurrying to pass legislation that conservationists say could make them even weaker. Lisa Cox unpicks the debate and explains the consequences if the new bill is passed for Australia’s unique wildlife and habitat
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Lisa Cox. Produced by Ellen Leabeater with assistance from Jake Morcom  and Miles Herbert. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: The wounded, the mourning and the defiant: inside the Christchurch sentencing
description: Over four days in the Christchurch high court, survivors of the 2019 mosque shootings and the families of victims stood up and faced the Australian gunman. In this episode of Full Story, we hear their statements, as Charlotte Graham-Mclay takes us inside the proceedings.
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Charlotte Graham-McLay. Produced by Cheyne Anderson and Belinda Lopez with Ryan Pemberton . The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: What has four years of Donald Trump meant for the climate crisis?
description: Guardian US reporter Emily Holden looks at the Trump administration’s impact on the environment, and the consequences if he wins another term
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Emily Holden. Produced by Hannah Moore and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Leonardo da Vinci and the mystery of the world's most expensive painting
description: Salvator Mundi sold for a record $450m at auction in 2017 to an anonymous bidder. But the painting’s provenance has been called into question
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Ben Lewis. Produced by Hannah Moore, Sam Colbert, Cheeka Eyers and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Australia's public servants and the right to free speech
description: Three months after writing about how Covid helped big tech, federal public servant Josh Krook was given a choice: remove the blog post or be sacked. Now, he’s speaking out about what he says is censorship. Reporter Christopher Knaus explores the case of Josh Krook and other public servants speaking out about the right to free speech.
contributors: Reported by Christopher Knaus and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Miles Herbert and Ryan Pemberton. The Executive Producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: A year of trouble for the royal family
description: Guardian columnist Hadley Freeman discusses the fallout from the publication of Finding Freedom, a biography of Harry and Meghan, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex, and the latest allegations surrounding Prince Andrew
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Hadley Freeman. Produced by Hannah Moore and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: The fight over the Aboriginal flag
description: At this year’s AFL Indigenous round, set up to celebrate Indigenous players and culture, there was one big change – the Aboriginal flag was not painted on the field. This was the result of a growing conflict about how the flag can be used, with AFL clubs and players, Indigenous companies and communities, and the minister for Indigenous Australians, all weighing in.Guardian Australia’s Indigenous affairs editor Lorena Allam explains the history of the flag and why it’s at the centre of such a bitter dispute
contributors: Reported by Lorena Allamand presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Adrian Walton, Miles Herbertand Ryan Pemberton. Executive producers areMiles Martignoniand Gabrielle Jackson

title: How Covid-19 could set back women by a generation
description: Unlike past recessions, this one has decimated predominantly female jobs. Women have also been affected by taking up the burden of homeschooling and care work. Some economists say the outcome could set back gender equality by a generation. Gabrielle Jackson speaks to Hex, who lost her job as a chef in Melbourne, and to Per Capita’s Emma Dawson about what the government can do
contributors: Hosted by Gabrielle Jackson and produced by Ellen Leabeater and Laura Murphy-Oates. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Why thousands of Australians are still stranded overseas
description: Thousands of Australians overseas have been trying to get home over the past few months, but have been hindered by cancelled flights and exorbitant airfares. This has left many stranded in unsafe, volatile environments, with money fast running out. On this episode of Full Story, Elias Visontay explains why this is happening and how it’s entirely avoidable
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Elias Visontay. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Miles Herbert. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Who are the people risking everything to cross the English Channel?
description: The number of migrants arriving to the UK in small boats this year is already double that of 2019. But those who manage to reach the country find themselves confronted by a government that is increasingly hostile to new arrivals
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Harriet Grant. Produced by Joshua Kelly and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Will Scott Morrison take responsibility for the aged care crisis in Victoria?
description: As Covid-19 tore through aged care homes during Victoria’s second wave, state and federal governments attempted to shift blame for the rising death toll. Political editor Katharine Murphy examines what has happened and who has ultimate responsibility
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Katharine Murphy. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: How Britain’s deepest recession is becoming a jobs crisis
description: Economics writer Aditya Chakrabortty describes how the coronavirus crisis has sent Britain plunging into a record recession and what it means for the millions of people fearing for their jobs
contributors: Presented by Mythili Rao with Aditya Chakrabortty. Produced by Courtney Yusuf and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson

title: No room to grieve: one Australian family experience death under Covid-19 restrictions
description: Emma Sheppard Simms tells us how she struggled with closing borders and mandatory quarantine to spend time with her dying father at the height of the coronavirus outbreak in north-west Tasmania
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and produced by Ellen Leabeater, Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: How Victoria's Covid-19 lockdown is devastating its economy
description: Before coronavirus, Victoria’s economy was powering ahead, but the tough lockdown as it endures a second wave has hit businesses hard. As companies close their doors and staff numbers are savagely cut, the state’s shutdown threatens to drag the rest of Australia even further into economic peril. Business correspondent Ben Butler explains how Victoria’s prosperity was dealt a succession of blows
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Ben Butler. Produced by Ellen Leabeater. The executive produces are Miles Martignoni and Mike Ticher

title: Can Kamala Harris help Joe Biden win the US presidency?
description: Kamala Harris is the first Indian American and the first black woman to run for US vice-president on a major party ticket. Lauren Gambino discusses why, as Joe Biden’s running mate, Harris is in prime position to go one step further
contributors: Presented by Mythili Rao and reported by Lauren Gambino.  Produced by Sam Colbert and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: After the bushfires: what can be done to save Australia's native species?
description: Last summer, bushfires burned through more than 12.6m hectares of the Australian landscape – an area almost the size of England. Reports that billions of individual animals were lost in the fires, pushing some native species to extinction, attracted global headlines. Environment reporter Graham Readfearn revisits the devastating story of Kangaroo Island in South Australia to explain the efforts to help local species survive, and discusses what needs to be done on a national level to protect wildlife from more catastrophic losses
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Graham Readfearn. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: Belarus: why are people protesting and could it bring down a president?
description: Thousands of protesters have taken to the streets in Belarus to contest the claimed election victory of the president, Alexander Lukashenko, and met a violent police response. Hanna Liubakova, a Belarusian journalist, describes being on the ground, while the Guardian’s Andrew Roth looks at how Lukashenko has remained in power for 26 years
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Hanna Liubakova and Andrew Roth. Produced by Sam Colbert and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are NNicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: After Beirut, grief and pain in the Australian Lebanese diaspora
description: Lebanese Australians are accustomed to bad news from Beirut, but last week’s explosion in the port, which killed at least 220 people and wrecked buildings across the city, brought a new kind of despair. Antoun Issa reflects on the weight of Lebanon’s violent past in Australian families, and the struggle to offer practical help in the aftermath of the explosion, amid the country’s economic chaos and entrenched political corruption
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Antoun Issa. Produced by Ellen Leabeater, Miles Herbert and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Mike Ticher.

title: Australia's national Covid-19 commission, gas pipelines and a troubling lack of transparency
description: The national Covid-19 commission was created to help steer the government through economic and social recovery from the pandemic. However, an interim report recommending large-scale investment in gas has raised alarm among energy and climate experts. Christopher Knaus explores what we know about the commission and concerns that key information is being withheld from the public
contributors: Reported by Christopher Knaus and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeaterand Joe Koning. Executive producers are Miles Martignoniand Gabrielle Jackson

title: After the Beirut explosion: anger, grief and the fall of a government
description: The deadly explosion that ripped through Beirut last week has left more than 200 people dead, thousands injured and hundreds of thousands displaced from their homes. The blast happened in a summer of already simmering tension in Lebanon as an economic crisis has taken a devastating toll on the country. The Guardian’s Martin Chulov, who is based in Beirut, describes the moment his apartment was rocked by the explosion – and what he witnessed that day. Middle East correspondent Bethan McKernan, who joined Beirut residents in the recovery effort in the days that followed, describes how grief turned to simmering anger, as those who lost their homes and loved ones took to the streets demanding answers and retribution. This episode first aired on Today in Focus, the Guardian’s global daily news podcast
contributors: Presented by Mythili Rao, and reported by Martin Chulov and Bethan McKernan. Produced by Joshua Kelly, Axel Kacoutié and Serena Barker-Singh. Additional production by Joe Koning. The executive producers of Today in Focus are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: Life under Covid-19 lockdown in Melbourne
description: Millions of people in Melbourne are living under the toughest lockdown laws in Australia, as Victoria tries to stem a fresh wave of coronavirus cases. Residents are subject to a curfew between 8pm and 5am, and police patrol the streets to enforce stringent restrictions on leaving the house, with even exercise and shopping severely limited. Writer Anna Spargo-Ryan and Guardian readers share their stories of life under lockdown, and how this time is very different from the first shutdown in March and April, when the whole of Australia was in roughly the same situation.
contributors: Featuring Anna Spargo-Ryan and presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeaterand Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: How did Donald Trump get his pandemic response so wrong?
description: While Donald Trump continues to claim the US is ‘doing very well’ in its fight against Covid-19, the figures suggest a different story. The US has the highest death toll in the world, with over 150,000 deaths. Guardian US chief reporter Ed Pilkington examines how Trump got it wrong
contributors: Presented by Mythili Rao and reported by Ed Pilkington. Produced by Joshua Kelly and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Finishing high school in a pandemic
description: The final year of high school is supposed to be challenging but also fun, full of things like your end of school formal, 18th birthday parties and at the end leaving school and becoming an adult. But this year has been different. Today we speak to a student about what the year’s felt like and what it means for their future
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: How the world is coping with coronavirus, six months on
description: From Portugal to Pakistan, the Guardian’s international correspondent Michael Safi looks at the different ways countries have been affected by the virus and the impact it is having on the lives of people
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Michael Safi. Produced by Serena Barker-Singh and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Nicole Jackson and Phil Maynard. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: How Covid-19 laid bare the cracks in Australia’s aged care system
description: With over half of Covid-19 deaths in Victoria associated with aged care facilities, the Australian Medical Association has called for a royal commission into the situation. But experts say there were warnings about the sector’s vulnerability stretching back many years. So how did this happen?
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Gay Alcorn and Sarah Russell. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Will a vaccine or recovery from the virus give us long-term immunity to Covid-19?
description: New evidence on how our bodies combat the virus has huge implications for the development of a coronavirus vaccine
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Ian Sample. Produced by Joshua Kelly and Nicholas Cox. Executive producers Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Inside the bitter struggle for control of Queensland's Liberal National party
description: Queensland is often a conservative stronghold in federal elections, but in recent years the Liberal National party has struggled to gain and hold power at state level. Now, three months away from an election, tensions in the LNP are on the rise. Ben Smee explains why backroom powerbrokers could be holding the party back
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Ben Smee. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. Executive produced by Miles Martignoni

title: Is Donald Trump playing politics with the Portland protests?
description: The anti-racism protests in Portland appeared to be dwindling in size until Donald Trump sent in federal officers to confront them, reports the Guardian’s Chris McGreal
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Chris McGreal. Produced by Sam Colbert, Rachel Humphreys and Nicholas Cox. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson. Adapted by Laura Murphy-Oates

title: Greg Jericho on what can you expect from the Covid-19 recession
description: Australia is experiencing its first recession in 30 years. It’s the worst economic crisis since the Great Depression and one like no other before it. Greg Jericho explains where the economy is at now, where we can expect it to take us and why this downturn is so different to others
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Greg Jericho. Produced by Joe Koning and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producer is Miles Martignoni

title: How Poland’s election puts at risk LGBT rights, the courts and the free press
description: A narrow win for the populist incumbent Andrzej Duda in Poland’s presidential election last week has cleared the path for the rightwing Law and Justice party to pursue anti-LGBT policies and further assault the courts and free press. The Guardian’s Christian Davies reports from Warsaw
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys and reported by Christian Davies. Produced by Courtney Yusuf and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson

title: What do we know about the long-term effects of Covid-19?
description: There is growing evidence from around the world that some people continue to experience debilitating symptoms of Covid-19 months after contracting the virus. They have been dubbed the ‘long-haulers’. Melissa Davey explains what we know about how patients in Australia who were diagnosed in March and April are recovering more than three months later
contributors: Presented by Gabrielle Jackson and reported by Melissa Davey. Produced by Joe Koning and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson.

title: Will we ever find life on Mars?
description: Planetary scientist Sarah Stewart Johnson describes how the latest mission to Mars builds on centuries of discoveries about the red planet – Earth’s nearest neighbour
contributors: Presented by Rachel Humphreys with Sarah Stewart Johnson. Produced by Hannah Moore and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are Phil Maynard and Nicole Jackson

title: 'Look what he’s taken from me': one man's fight against child abuse in the church
description: On the island of Guam, the church is at the centre of everyday life, but the community is going through a reckoning, as person after person comes forward with stories of being sexually abused by priests. Today we speak to one alter boy, Walter Denton, about his search for justice and how he helped bring change to the island.
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Anita Hofschneider. Produced by Joe Koning and Ellen Leabeater. The executive producers are and Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Why the advice on wearing masks has changed
description: Wearing masks in Melbourne is now mandatory with $200 fines for those not wearing them outside the home. This is a first for Australia, but the enforced wearing of masks has been legislated in numerous countries around the world, particularly in the past few weeks. So why are the rules changing?
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by Graham Readfearn. Produced by Ellen Leabeater . The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Life inside Melbourne’s public housing towers
description: On 4 July, police surrounded nine public housing towers in Melbourne, locking around 3,000 residents inside due to fears of an uncontrolled spread of Covid-19. But the police presence triggered fear in the community because of a history of over-policing in this multicultural, tight-knit community. Nor Shanino and Ahmed Dini tell us about what it was like to grow up in the towers and the incredible resilience of their residents
contributors: Presented by Laura Murphy-Oates and reported by James Button. Produced by Ellen Leabeater and Joe Koning. The executive producers are Miles Martignoni and Gabrielle Jackson

title: Who is Ghislaine Maxwell and does she hold the key to justice for Epstein’s victims?
description: Ghislaine Maxwell, a British socialite and daughter of the media baron Robert Maxwell, once attended parties with princes, presidents and celebrities. Now she faces up to 35 years in a US prison for her alleged involvement in Jeffrey Epstein’s sex trafficking of underage girls
contributors: Presented by Anushka Asthana and reported by Mark Seal and Victoria Bekiempis. Produced by Sam Colbert and Axel Kacoutié. The executive producers are NNicole Jackson and Phil Maynard

title: Facebook, white nationalists and becoming the target of a hate campaign
description: In November, Julia Carrie Wong reported on the continued presence of white nationalist organisations on Facebook – and a weeks-long campaign of racist and sexist harassment followed.
